translated: Verses of the Elder Monks 16.1
Verses of the Elders🔽The Twentieth Chapter🔽The First Chapter
Adhimutta

analyzed: yañña ttham vā dhana ttham vā
translated: For the sake of sacrifice or wealth,
we used to kill in the past.
There was fear for the rest,
they were wounded and wailed.
But you have no fear,
your complexion is even more radiant.
Why do you not lament,
in such a great danger?”
“There is no mental suffering,
for one who is heedless, village chief.
Having transcended all fears,
for one whose fetters are destroyed.
When the guide to existence is destroyed,
in this very life as it truly is;
There is no fear of death,
like the destruction of diseases.
The spiritual life has been well-lived for me,
and the path has been well-developed.
I have no fear of death,
like the destruction of diseases.
The spiritual life has been well-lived for me,
and the path has been well-developed.

analyzed: nirassādā bhavā diṭṭhā  visam pitvā ava chaḍḍita
translated: Existence has been seen to be without essence,🔽like poison discarded.
Having gone beyond, without clinging,
having done what was to be done, without defilements;
One is content at the end of life,
as if released from a murder.
Having attained the supreme state of Dhamma,
not seeking anything in the world,
as if released from a burning house,
he does not grieve over death.
Whatever there is that is connected,
or any kind of existence that is obtained,
all of that is not escape,
this was said by the Great Sage.
One who understands it as such,
as taught by the Buddha,
does not grasp at any kind of existence,
like a heated lump of iron.🔽I do not have ‘I was,’
I do not have ‘I will be in the future’;
The formations will depart,
what is there to lament about that?
The pure arising of phenomena,
the pure continuity of formations;
Seeing them as they really are,

analyzed: na bhayam gāmaṇi  tiṇa kaṭṭha samam loka
translated: there is no fear, O village headman.🔽When one sees the world as equal to grass and wood,

analyzed: yadā paññāya passati  mamattam saḥ asavinda
translated: with wisdom,🔽not clinging to ‘mine,’
‘I do not have’ he does not grieve.
I am disgusted with the body,
I do not seek for existence;
This body will break up,
and another will not come to be.
Whatever you have to do with your bodies,
Do it, if you so wish;
I have no fault there,
Nor do I have any love for it.”
Having heard his words,
Which were wondrous and caused the hair to stand on end,
The students put down their weapons🔽And spoke thus to the young man:

analyzed: kim bhadante karitvāna  kaḥ vai tava
translated: “What, venerable sir, have you done,🔽Or who is your teacher?
By whose instruction have you attained
That state of sorrowlessness?”
“The Omniscient One, the All-Seeing One,
The Victor is my teacher;
The Greatly Compassionate Teacher,
The Healer of the Whole World.
By him this Dhamma has been taught,
Which leads to destruction, which is unsurpassed;
By his instruction one attains
That state of sorrowlessness.”
Having heard the sage’s good words,
The thieves put down their weapons and their tools,
And some of them refrained from that deed,

original: Eke ca pabbajjamarocayiṁsu.🔽Te pabbajitvā sugatassa sāsane,
analyzed: eke ca pabbajjam arocayisu  te pabbajitvā sugatassa sāsane
translated: And some of them chose to go forth.🔽Having gone forth in the Well-Gone One’s Dispensation,
The wise ones developed the factors of enlightenment,
With uplifted minds, joyful, with faculties composed,
They have touched the deathless state, the unconditioned.
… The Elder Adhimutta …
